qas.question: When was the term copy-text introduced?
What was the initial definition of copy-text?

answers.text: the text used in each particular case as the basis of mine

qas.question: Explain the process used by McKerrow as an alternative to the stemmaic method

answers.text: choose one particular text that was thought to be particularly reliable, and then to emend it only where the text was obviously corrupt.

qas.question: When was Ronald B. McKerrow born?
What year did Thomas Nashe introduce the term copy-text?
Thomas Nash is a bibliographer who published whose works?
Nashe was aware of limitations of which method?
Ronald B. McKerror was a french critic who did like which method?

context: The bibliographer <b5_0>Ronald B. McKerrow<b5_0/> introduced the term copy-text in his <a0_0><b3_0><b4_0>1904<b4_0/><b3_0/><a0_0/> edition of the works of Thomas Nashe, defining it as "<a1_0>the text used in each particular case as the basis of mine<a1_0/>." McKerrow was aware of the limitations of the <b6_0>stemmatic method<b6_0/>, and believed it was more prudent to <a2_0>choose one particular text that was thought to be particularly reliable, and then to emend it only where the text was obviously corrupt.<a2_0/> The French critic Joseph Bédier likewise became disenchanted with the <b7_0>stemmatic method<b7_0/>, and concluded that the editor should choose the best available text, and emend it as little as possible.
